qas.question: What made Arius's belief about Jesus different from Alexander's?

answers.text: Son (Logos) of God, made, not begotten

qas.question: Was this differing view common among Christians of the day?
When did Athanasius become a deacon?
When did Arius become a deacon?
When did Athanasius become a bishop?

plausible_answers.text: Son (Logos) of God, made, not begotten

qas.question: What made Arius's belief about Jesus the same from Alexander's?
What other leaders did not believe this?

context: In about <b4_0><b5_0><b7_0>319<b7_0/><b5_0/><b4_0/>, when Athanasius was a deacon, a presbyter named Arius came into a direct conflict with Alexander of <b6_0>Alexandria<b6_0/>. It appears that Arius reproached Alexander for what he felt were misguided or heretical teachings being taught by the bishop. Arius's theological views appear to have been firmly rooted in Alexandrian Christianity, and his Christological views were certainly not radical at all. He embraced a subordinationist Christology which taught that Christ was the divine <a0_0><b9_0>Son (Logos) of God, made, not begotten<b9_0/><a0_0/>, heavily influenced by Alexandrian thinkers like Origen, and which was a <a1_0>common Christological view<a1_0/> in <b8_0>Alexandria<b8_0/> at the time. Support for Arius from <a2_0>powerful bishops<a2_0/> like Eusebius of Caesarea and Eusebius of Nicomedia, further illustrate how Arius's subordinationist Christology was shared by other Christians in the Empire. <b11_0>Arius<b11_0/> was subsequently <a3_0>excommunicated by Alexander<a3_0/>, and he would begin to elicit the support of many <b10_0>bishops<b10_0/> who agreed with his position.
